# Experience Data Model (XDM)

Experience Data Model (XDM) is an Adobe initiative to expand and standardize the way data is used in customer centric applications. XDM provides a normalizing data schema into which data might be ingested, codified, queried, accessed, manipulated, and shared. The end-user advantage of data standardization resides in a unified data ecosystem within which data from many disparate sources becomes consolidated by way of a standard structure, and consequently amenable to the ever-evolving needs of data applications.

For example, campaign managers might seek to create a specific target market (see Segmentation) for a specific customer profile (see Unified Profile) using varied data representations of behavioral, operational and end-user data sources, e.g. people with blue eyes, brown hair, etc. In this case, XDM offers the utility of a highly standardized, structured, and normalized data environment with which to create a custom target market of unique customer attributes. Moreover, XDM provides for further customization of data by way of _extensibility_â€“adding new abstract schemas and fields to XDM standard schemas. This standardized single-source data structure ultimately affords end-users of XDM full control over how, where, and when they apply abstract data to concrete market campaigns (see Campaign).

# The Architecture of XDM

The design of XDM schemas accommodates, arranges, and standardizes data from sources that use disparate data schema structures. Data housed in disparate data schema structures succumbs to the inherent liabilities of data isolation; that is, data that cannot interrelate with external data solutions, such as those offered through Adobe. The design of Adobe&#39;s standard schematization solves the problem of data isolation and allows for data impartiality, such that data becomes malleable for purposes of data management and articulation. If not for standardization, data would remain otherwise isolated at its source, and therefore unable to find accord with the broad spectrum of essential data solutions.

# Components of XDM

The Adobe Experience Data Model (XDM) is comprised of an hierarchical data structure based on proprietary standard data schemas, abstract/sub schemas, fields, and primitives. This hierarchical structure is primarily governed (syntax and semantics) by way of JSON-Schema.

- XDM Standard Schemas
- Abstract/Sub Schemas
- Fields
- Primitives

This normalizing data environment also includes the option of customizing standard XDM schemas. This is accomplished through the use of extensibility, or _extensions_ (see Extensions), the likes of which provision the user of XDM to align non-standard datasets with standard XDM schemas. In essence, extending standard data schemas allows for a sophisticated, personalized data structure, one that facilitates a more refined and precise market campaign.

 ![](data:image/*;base64,)

# How XDM Works

The transferring of partner data into XDM schemas begins with the mapping of data. Data wranglers isolate fields from their own database and align them with the corresponding XDM schema syntax and semantics. This mapping provides for the seamless introduction of partner datasets into XDM schemas. The next step involves the extraction of data, which requires the partner to generate a dataset from its own data store. Once this dataset is created, it is then ready for transformation. This transformation includes translating the partner&#39;s dataset into an XDM schema-compatible arrangement. The final step entails the transference/loading of this dataset from the partner&#39;s system to the Adobe Cloud Platform.

#
XDM Standard Schemas

Over time, Adobe has evolved and increased its range of standard schemas to include the following:

- ExperienceEvent
- PhysicalLocation
- Product
- Profile
- Segment
- Store

### ExperienceEvent

The ExperienceEvent standard schema engenders specific data parameters that allow the end-user of XDM to model data that concerns events, i.e._what_ occurred and _when_. Time domain analytics relies on such data for scrutinizing singular fluctuations in observable behavior, e.g. website visits, product views, hardware and software use, etc. The modeling of this kind of data offers end-users of XDM an unobstructed viewpoint from which to survey changes in events that occur in windows of time, and therefore to track trends and customize market campaigns to meet precise industry specifications.

### PhysicalLocation

The PhysicalLocation standard schema engenders specific data parameters that allow the end-user of XDM to model data that concerns maintains data pertaining to an individual&#39;s/groups&#39; physical location. _[yes, it can also be just the location of a thing like a store, point of interest that is then used to see if a person is in the location]_

### Product

The Product standard schema engenders specific data parameters that allow the end-user of XDM to model data that concerns maintains data pertaining to consumer products and consumer preferences. _[We feel that it will also include non-consumer products, Also it is very specific, Product contains the information the vendor maintains about the products. Including categorization and relationship information between products. Customers may see some of this data, but often the data a customer sees about a product is refined for that moment. So a Product record would changes very slowly, maybe never. But the way a customer sees a product is specific to the context they are viewing it, and that view is really related to the XEvent, not this Product]_

### Profile

The Profile standard schema engenders specific data parameters that allow the end-user of XDM to model data that concerns attributes of identified and partially-identified persons. Profiles that are highly-identified can be used for personal communications or focused market campaigns, as they contain detailed personal information (such as names, genders, dates of birth, geo-locations) and contact information (such as phone numbers and email addresses). Profiles that are less mature and deficient in concrete identifying characteristics contain only anonymous behavioral events, such as browser cookies. Nevertheless, this sparse data can be used to create the foundation of a highly-identified profile. That is, by way of storing information on interests and preferences of an anonymous person, the Profile standard schema accommodates more robust and detailed data. And as the individual interacts more frequently with the user interface of a brand, the further refined the profile becomes in classifiable details, until eventually this person signs-on to notifications, subscriptions, purchases and other connections with the brand that enrich and round out the profile.

maintains data pertaining to personal information, e.g. physical address, phone number, city, state, region, etc. _[We are adding calculated results that represent computed information about the user from their ExperienceEvents. These will be things like productsViewed, lifeTimeValue etc]_

### Segment

The Segment standard schema engenders specific data parameters that allow the end-user of XDM to model data that concerns

### Store

The Store standard schema engenders specific data parameters that allow the end-user of XDM to model data that concerns

# XDM Extensibility

Adobe&#39;s standard schemas offer partners the ability to model data into a common data ecosystem governed by standardizing syntax and semantics. This normalization of data allows for the interoperability between partner data and Adobe solutions, which affords access to any number of Adobe functionsâ€”including analytics. Moreover, XDM schema protocols provision the end-user to add new schemas, or to _extend_ XDM standard schemas, features that personalize schemas to the unique specifications maintained by Adobe partners.

# XDM and Adobe Solutions
